item.title: Ticket #2190 (Imge upload and suexec problem) updated
item.dc:creator: ryan
item.description:
It works okay for me. Look in the save() function in wp-includes/cache.php. See the following code: 

		// Make the base cache dir.
		if (!file_exists($this->cache_dir)) {
			if (! @ mkdir($this->cache_dir))
				return false;
			@ chmod($this->cache_dir, $dir_perms);
		}

Remove the "@" characters to enable verbose output. Maybe that will tell us what's going on.

item.title: Ticket #2328 (Provide structured access to category list) updated
item.dc:creator: davidhouse
item.description:
Attached patch puts the categories array through list_cats_cats before building the list. That should be structured enough.

Notice that you can already manipulate list_cats_exclusions to do what you want: 

function list_cats_handler($exs) {
    global $excluded_categories;
    $exs .= 'AND cat_id != ' . implode($excluded_categories, ' AND cat_id != ');
}
add_filter('list_cats_cats', 'list_cats_handler');

However it'd be nice to have the general, more structured hook available anyway.

item.title: Ticket #2330 (Add filter for posts_nav_link) updated
item.dc:creator: coppit
item.description: Summary changed

item.title: Ticket #2330 (Add filter for posts_nav_link) created
item.dc:creator: coppit
item.description:
My Category Access plugin hides posts in restricted categories. posts_nav_link puts a next page link on a page for which all the posts have been hidden. Tracing it a bit, it looks like is_single might be a good place to tweak things, but I don't see a hook to do so.

Perhaps the function should provide a category exclusion in line with my other request: ​http://trac.wordpress.org/ticket/2327

See my original post on wp-hackers here: ​http://comox.textdrive.com/pipermail/wp-hackers/2006-January/004096.html

item.title: Ticket #2329 (Add filter for wp_get_archives) created
item.dc:creator: coppit
item.description:
My Category Access plugin hides posts in restricted categories. wp_get_archives doesn't have a hook for me to fix the count. For example, if a month has 20 posts, but 4 are inaccessible, I'd like to reduce the post count to 16.

See my original post on wp-hackers here: ​http://comox.textdrive.com/pipermail/wp-hackers/2006-January/004096.html

item.title: Ticket #2328 (Provide structured access to category list) created
item.dc:creator: coppit
item.description:
list_cats is an ugly way to filter the category list. Can you add a filter that passes a category list data structure for filtering, instead of the HTML? As things are now, I have to parse the HTML permalink structure in order to figure out the category, and then rebuild the HTML based on my modifications.

See ​http://comox.textdrive.com/pipermail/wp-hackers/2006-January/004106.html for my original post on wp-hackers.

item.title: Ticket #2327 (Process previous/next post navigation with category exclusions) created
item.dc:creator: coppit
item.description:
There should be a call to the list_cats_exclusions filter from within get_next_post and get_previous_post, similar to the way it's already done in list_cats.

This way plugin authors can hook list_cats_exclusions and modify the accessible posts in both the category list and the navigational post links.

For example, my Category Access plugin hides posts in particular categories. Without the requested hook, my plugin can't avoid the next post pointing to a post that should be hidden from the user.

item.title: Ticket #2209 (wp-mail chokes when sender name contains apostrophe, e.g: O'Donahue) updated
item.dc:creator: majelbstoat
item.description:
Cc, Keywords, Milestone changed

Possible patch uploaded. Simply calls addslashes() on the author's name before it goes to the database call. The patch also changes $tableusers to $wpdb->users (couldn't see a reason why it was still like that) and also removes the ORDER BY ID DESC restriction on the query, which is unnecessary due to LIMIT 1. I don't use post by email so it's untested and put together after a quick examination, but it might do the trick. Needs someone else to have a look at it though.

item.title: Ticket #2326 (add_query_arg incorrectly sets uri with arguments of associative array ...) updated
item.dc:creator: majelbstoat
item.description: Milestone changed

item.title: fix for uri in add_query_arg.diff attached to Ticket #2326
item.dc:creator: majelbstoat
item.description: Patch to provide proper uri base when calling add_query_arg with an associative array and no existing uri.

item.title: Ticket #2326 (add_query_arg incorrectly sets uri with arguments of associative array ...) created
item.dc:creator: majelbstoat
item.description:
Currently, if you call this:

add_query_arg(array('key' => 'val'));

the uri is generated from the non-existant func_get_arg(1) , which always returns an empty string. The patch supplied checks to see if a second argument exists and if it doesn't uses the request uri instead.

item.title: Ticket #2321 (Array union in generate_rewrite_rules doesn't achieve expected effect.) updated
item.dc:creator: majelbstoat
item.description: In any case, here is a patch that converts all the array union operators in classes.php to an array_merge call. There were 6 or 7 in total, making it a more comprehensive patch than the previous one. Assuming the overhead of a function call is negligible this would be a better solution. In any case, you can decide which one to use. Tested and working on PHP 4.3.4 and 4.3.11 on latest SVN.

item.title: array_merge to replace array union.diff attached to Ticket #2321
item.dc:creator: majelbstoat
item.description: Alternative patch that replaces unions with array_merge

item.title: Ticket #2321 (Array union in generate_rewrite_rules doesn't achieve expected effect.) updated
item.dc:creator: majelbstoat
item.description: I thought about that, but it does involve the overhead of a function call, when it is only a simple prepend...

item.title: Ticket #2268 (get_option() on non-existent option always invokes new query) updated
item.dc:creator: markjaquith
item.description: What we should probably do, until this is fixed, is educate plugin authors about their settings. When their plugin management page loads, it should check all the plugins options and add_option() for any of its options that does not yet exist, populating it with a default value. Too many plugin authors have been using options as on/off switches, and assuming "does not exists" == false.

item.title: Ticket #2319 (file_get_contents is PHP 4.3+, docs says PHP 4.2 ok) updated
item.dc:creator: markjaquith
item.description: I don't think implode will return false, which is why you need that extra line

item.title: Ticket #2319 (file_get_contents is PHP 4.3+, docs says PHP 4.2 ok) updated
item.dc:creator: markjaquith
item.description:
This is what I've been using in one of my plugins... not sure where I got it: 

/* compatibility with PHP versions older than 4.3 */
if ( !function_exists('file_get_contents') ) {
   function file_get_contents($file) {
       $file = file($file);
       return !$file ? false : implode('', $file);
   }
}

item.title: Ticket #2123 (Custom 404 stops working when using /%category%/%postname%/ as ...) updated
item.dc:creator: majelbstoat
item.description: In fact, for the permalink structure described, this will require 2 db accesses. A better solution, may be to skip further db accesses if the first one returns a 404. Thoughts?

item.title: 404 non existant posts, authors and cats.diff attached to Ticket #2123
item.dc:creator: majelbstoat
item.description: 404 when an invalid postname / category / authorname is supplied

item.title: Ticket #2123 (Custom 404 stops working when using /%category%/%postname%/ as ...) updated
item.dc:creator: majelbstoat
item.description:
Keywords changed

This can't really be avoided at the rewrite stage because the (.+?) clause that replaces /%category%/ will catch everything. The same thing will probably happen for permalink structures that start with /%postname%/ or /%author%/ . One solution is to insert a check in parse_query() to see if the supplied variable is an existant cat/author/postname and set a 404 from there if it isn't.

The supplied patch does this, at a cost of one extra db access per test for category or author or postname-specified singles. Of these, the biggest hit will be the postname db access, used in a more 'traditional' structure of /%year%/%monthnum%/%day%/%postname%/ . However, with caching, this may be an acceptable tradeoff, resulting in an extra access only for a non-existant request (the thinking being that requests for pages that exist will already be cached).

This works for me in latest SVN.

item.title: Ticket #2218 (Pop-up window for inserting hyperlinks truncated on FireFox 1.5) updated
item.dc:creator: howtoblog
item.description:
Priority changed

I'm using WinXP Media Center Edition with service pack 2 installed. I'm sorry I did not check back on the status of this ticket until now.

Prior to checking back on this ticket status, I recently added several new Firefox extensions and all of a sudden the dialog box from WP is no longer truncated.(See below for my list of extensions - I noticed the change after installing SpellBound, Mozilla SpellCheck Libraries, and Performancing)

So the problem is definately related somehow to the use of Firefox extensions. The ones I have installed are:

DOM Inspector 1.8

Talkback 1.5

Auto Copy 0.6.0

FlashGot 0.5.9.99

Adsense Notifier 0.7

ConQuery 1.6.2

LinkChecker 0.4.3

Copy Links 0.1.3

Context Highlight 0.2

TargetKiller 0.3

Sage 1.3.6

Google Pagerank Status 0.9.3

DownThemAll! 0.9.8.4

Copy URL+ 1.3.2

Disable Targets For Downloads 1.0

IE View 1.2.7

BetterSearch 1.9

SpellBound 0.7.3

Mozilla SpellCheck Libraries 1.0.1.0

Performancing 1.0.1

Google Toolbar for Firefox 1.0.20051122

I don't know if the fact that it is due to a Firefox extension makes it not a WP issue or not, but at least now you're aware of it (and I honestly don't know why adding new extensions fixed the problem, but I'm glad they did as I hate using IE)
